title: 106_s3118
content: The Act may be cited as the "Windfall Oil Profits For Heating Assistance Act of 2000". It includes findings and purpose. Congress finds that in the second quarter of 2000, the net income of major petroleum companies more than doubled compared to the same period in 1999, reaching $10.3 billion. Profits for companies like BP Amoco, Chevron Corporation, Conoco, Exxon Mobil Corporation, Marathon Oil Company, Phillips Petroleum Company, Royal Dutch/Shell Group, and Texaco, Inc. also saw significant increases. In the second quarter of 2000, profits soared for major petroleum companies: BP Amoco by 133%, Chevron by 136%, Conoco by 205%, Exxon Mobil by 123%, Marathon by 208%, Phillips by 275%, Shell by 96%, and Texaco by 124%. These profits were record quarterly earnings for BP Amoco, Chevron, Conoco, Exxon Mobil, and Shell. In the first quarter of 2000, ARCO reported $333 million in profits, BP Amoco $2.68 billion, Chevron $1.1 billion, Conoco $391 million, Exxon Mobil $3.35 billion, Phillips $250 million, Shell $3.13 billion, and Texaco $602 million. In the first quarter of 2000, profits significantly increased for major petroleum companies: ARCO by 136%, BP Amoco by 296%, Chevron by 291%, Conoco by 371%, Exxon Mobil by 108%, Phillips by 257%, Shell by 117%, and Texaco by 473%. BP Amoco, Conoco, Exxon Mobil, and Shell reported record quarterly profits. Gasoline prices reached all-time highs in the US on June 19, 2000, with a national average of $1.68 per gallon. Heating oil inventories were estimated to be significantly lower in 2000 compared to 1999. American consumers are facing high gasoline prices, with home heating oil prices expected to reach record highs in the winter of 2000-2001. The oil industry is making record profits, prompting the need to transfer windfall profits to fund heating assistance for consumers and small business owners. SEC. 3. WINDFALL PROFITS ADJUSTMENT. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to impose a tax on windfall profits from crude oil and its products. An excise tax is imposed on windfall profits from domestic crude oil or taxable products removed from premises at a rate of 100 percent. Definitions include premises, producer, reasonable profit, and taxable product. The excise tax is imposed on windfall profits from domestic crude oil or taxable products, exceeding a reasonable profit. The tax is to be paid by the producer, and regulations will be prescribed by the Secretary. Chapter 55 addresses windfall profits on crude oil and products, with amendments effective from January 1, 2000. The Federal Trade Commission is tasked with investigating and determining reasonable profits. The Federal Trade Commission will investigate oil industry profits, including major petroleum companies, on sales in the US after January 1, 1999. They will determine reasonable profits for applying the Internal Revenue Code. Funding will be provided for this investigation. Revenues from windfall oil profits will be allocated to heating assistance. Establishment of Trust Fund for Windfall Oil Profits under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Establishment of the 'Windfall Oil Profits Trust Fund' in the Treasury of the United States under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Appropriation of taxes to the fund and allocation for heating assistance for consumers. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 establishes the 'Windfall Oil Profits Trust Fund' in the Treasury of the United States. A new item is added to the table of sections for subchapter A of chapter 98 of subtitle I, allowing for heating assistance for small businesses. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 establishes the 'Windfall Oil Profits Trust Fund' in the Treasury of the United States, allowing for heating assistance for small businesses. Sec. 9511 pertains to the Windfall oil profits trust fund.
